final_answer:
The humor in this image comes from its play on the concept of exclusivity and convenience, which the FastPass is meant to represent. The left panel shows a figure holding a FastPass card, indicating a streamlined, quick access experience. 

However, the right panel reveals the irony: both the regular and FastPass entrances are right next to each other, leading to the same place. With people in line for the FastPass entrance, it suggests that the supposed expedited access may not be as special or advantageous as expected. The "YES, BUT" text emphasizes this discrepancy between expectation and reality, adding a satirical twist to the idea of paying for a service that ultimately offers no real benefit.
ground_truth: The image is ironic, because fast pass entrance was meant for people to pass the gate fast but as more no. of people bought the pass due to which the queue has become longer and it becomes slow and time consuming
